comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: It was in the area of Kelly's Corner. From this page: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portobello,_Dublin "Starting in the 1980s Kelly's Corner was re-developed. Old Camden Street and Charlotte Street disappeared and the ruined buildings there made way for the Camden Court Hotel. The north side of Harcourt road was developed, Stein's the opticians being the last to go in the first phase, and Gleeson's pub in the second." See also: www.excavations.ie/Pages/Details.php?Year=1996&County...

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: So we are in the vicinity of the "Bleeding Horse" pub, presumably? In the 1980's, you used to come along the South Circular road, turn left onto the first bit of Camden Street, turn right and double back onto the SCR via what I think was Charlotte Street, then go along the SCR and left again onto the very top of Harcourt Street........ This shows the scene today, g.co/maps/v6g5t - you now go along Charlotte Way to get to Harcourt Street!

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/apl-irl/7080048995/in/photostream This edited Google pic shows where Charlotte Place was.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] Thanks a million! That's a great help... Think this is one of the first times that one of our photos depicts a street that just does not exist any more - not changed dramatically, but just completely obliterated!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Wow! That's great - explains the odd arrangement of roads there - the abrupt end to Charlemont St and the little curved road onto Sth Richmond St. (It is cool to play with the overlay feature on OSI!)

So was Charlotte Place above or below the second T in Charlotte on the OS map I wonder? Seems the most likely place.

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content: Answering my own question - looks like Charlotte Place was to the left as you walked uphill, so it must have been on the Harcourt St side of the street - can just make it out in OS map.

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Looking at 1901 census, James Kavanagh (27) was a hair-dresser on Charlotte St. He wasn't married. He had three sisters Mary (31) Kate (29) and Ellen (17). By 1911, James married and had two daughters Ellen (3) and Martha (1).

I suppose it seems more likely that the daughters rather than the sisters became the "Kavanagh Sisters" in 1964?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] Fantastic, Michael! So, in 1911 at 8.1 Charlotte Street, we've Ellen (3) and Martha (1). At 8.2 Charlotte Street, there's also Willie Kavanagh, a "male relative" listed as a "Hairdresser Improver" so obviously hairdressing was in the Kavanagh blood. By 1964, Ellen and Martha would have been 56 and 54 respectively, and there may even have been other Kavanagh girls (not born in 1911) who made up the team at Kavanagh Sisters...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Like it - a "Hairdresser Improver"! Checked Thom's 1862. No. 8 was a surgeon. But there was a barber - Mr George - at No. 12. Interestingly in 1862, No. 7 (which I guess is the house being demolished) was occupied by John Byrne - a carpenter and builder. Some things never change!
